The company, doing business as Deutsche Post DHL, had 2020 revenue of 66.81 billion euros, equivalent to about $75.7 billion, up 5.5% from 2019 and nearly 30% from 2010. This year, the company forecasts record earnings of more than $8.7 billion. Currently the chief executive of the company’s German post and parcel division, Mr. Meyer joined the business in 2013 and has held leadership roles including chief operations officer at DHL’s global-forwarding unit, which coordinates the shipment of goods from one destination to another using a range of transport options. He became a member of the company’s management board in 2019. Mr. Meyer “is the ideal choice to continue the very successful path the company has charted,”

      chairman of the Deutsche Post AG’s supervisory board, said in a statement.  Top news and in-depth analysis on the world of logistics, from supply chain to transport and technology. Title: Subscription Companies Rethink Irksome Cancelation Practices  - WSJ
Text:
https://www.wsj.com/articles/subscription-companies-rethink-irksome-cancelation-practices-11638370800 Signing up for a membership has always been easier than canceling it. While subscribing to an app, newspaper, gym or other service may now be as simple as pressing a button on a smartphone, many companies still push customers to dial a number and speak to an agent to cancel. But the common “click to subscribe, call to cancel” practice may be waning. Several companies say they plan to introduce easier ways for customers to cancel without the rigmarole of calling, as federal and state authorities home in on regulating deceptive and unfair user-experience designs. The shift even touches pay TV, a category notorious for tenacious efforts to prevent customers from leaving. A spokesman for satellite service










            DirecTV


      LLC, which allows customers to sign up online, said it plans to introduce a click-to-cancel mechanism for streaming customers next year.  DirecTV streaming customers who sign up on a month-to-month service agreement online currently must call or speak to a representative on a web chat to cancel, the spokesman said, adding that satellite customers must still call to cancel. Companies tweaking their cancelation processes say they are doing so to make things easier for customers. Such changes also come as regulators and lawmakers are beginning to crack down on companies that employ user-experience design that tricks or traps consumers into subscriptions—including practices that make subscriptions cumbersome to cancel. The Federal Trade Commission last month said it plans to ramp up enforcement against the use of illegal “dark patterns,” including deceptive sign-up tactics, and told businesses to “provide cancelation mechanisms that are at least as easy to use as the method the consumer used to buy the product or service in the first place.” The FTC said it reviews cancelation policies on a case-by-case basis, examining the barriers to simple cancelation rather than the method itself.  Get weekly insights into the ways companies optimize data, technology and design to drive success with their customers and employees.   Meanwhile California Gov. Gavin Newsom in October signed a package of amendments to the state’s law on automatic subscription renewals, including a requirement that companies let customers cancel subscriptions online without “engaging any further steps that obstruct or delay the consumer’s ability to terminate immediately.” The law takes effect July 1, 2022, bolstering California’s existing rule that customers who accept an automatic renewal or continuous service offer online must be able to cancel the service online. Companies have long used design techniques to manipulate subscribers’ spending behavior, but some enter “dark patterns” territory when they use design to hide information to encourage a consumer to sign up or keep subscribing, said









      
      Harry Brignull,



      a user-experience designer who studies deceptive user interfaces. That includes failing to remind customers when an annual subscription is renewing; advertising a cheaper, first-month deal in a large font; and onerous “call-to-cancel” policies, which can make it harder to get out of a membership than it is to join, said Dr. Brignull, who has a PhD in cognitive science. Requiring a phone call is an effective business tactic because it adds two layers of friction between the customer and the door, Dr. Brignull said: having to call in the first place, often at a stipulated and sometimes inconvenient time, and then navigating a retention specialist’s pitches. Getting a customer to talk on the phone sometimes lets companies understand and offer exactly what it might take to make them stay, such as a discount or a few months’ free service, he added. Companies planning or contemplating moves toward easier cancelations include










            Planet Fitness Inc.,


      which lets customers join online as well as in-person but does not let the majority of members quit online or even by phone. The gym chain asks members to visit or write a letter to their local gym to cancel, although it has made online cancelation options available to customers in markets like California with regulations about online cancelations.  “We are currently evaluating our membership management policies and are exploring ways to evolve them to provide additional options and convenience,” said









      
      McCall Gosselin,



      senior vice president of communications and corporate responsibility at Planet Fitness. 









      
      Karl Wells,



      chief subscriptions officer for Wall Street Journal parent Dow Jones & Co., said the newspaper is testing “new ways to provide subscribers with a more flexible approach to managing their subscription preferences,” and expects to expand those in the coming months. Dow Jones already lets its Barron’s, MarketWatch and WSJ Student subscribers cancel online but requires Wall Street Journal subscribers to cancel via phone call. Customers in markets with digital-cancelation laws can cancel online, a spokeswoman said. 

 Bloomberg Media, which previously told customers to cancel by filling in an online form, in April introduced a live chatbot that lets users cancel a subscription by exchanging a few messages, a spokesman for the company said. Not all companies are leaving telephone requirements in the past, however. The Washington Post said that while digital subscribers can cancel online, customers must still call to cancel print subscriptions, even though they can subscribe to them online. “We are focused on creating an excellent experience for digital subscribers, the area where we are seeing vast subscriber growth,” said









      
      Michael Ribero,



      chief subscriptions officer at the Washington Post. “We have a very stable print subscriber base, and as such, we have maintained a simple process of calling to cancel a print subscription.” Write to Katie Deighton at katie.deighton@wsj.com Copyright ©2021 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Title: U.K. Soccer Stadiums Design for Safer Standing at Games  - WSJ
Text: https://www.wsj.com/articles/soccer-stadiums-design-for-safer-standing-at-games-11637348909 British soccer teams are poised to begin a test that could allow passionate fans to once again stand up during matches without breaking the rules. The U.K. government is backing a trial of “safe standing” areas, in which new railings separate rows to prevent fans from falling forward. The government in 1990 mandated that top-level games be played in all-seated stadiums, a reaction to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster in which 97 soccer fans died as a result of a crush in standing-only pens at a stadium in Sheffield. Nearly every club in the top two leagues of English and Welsh soccer converted their stadiums’ standing areas, which often comprised nothing more than a set of concrete bleachers, into seated areas by the mid-1990s, and began telling fans to stay in those seats. But adding seats and rules did not compel all fans to stop standing or eliminate the possibility that they could topple onto spectators below them, causing injury or even a phenomenon called progressive crowd collapse, whereby the forward fall of one person from the back leads to a crushing domino effect. “The analogy we always use is, when you go to church and sing your hymns, you stand up,” said Peter Daykin, a board member of the Football Supporters’ Association and coordinator of its Safe Standing campaign. “There’s kind of a visceral enjoyment in that for some people.” Now, just over 20 years since the so-called all-seater legislation was passed, the teams and authorities that regulate soccer in England and Wales have designed stadium sections that account for fans’ natural game day behavior, rather than trying to control it. Five clubs—Cardiff City, Chelsea, Manchester United, Manchester City and Tottenham Hotspur—will begin formally testing the approach in January. Some teams in the trial have already installed safety railings in areas of their stadiums known for persistent standing. There is no Hillsborough-style tragedy prompting the British test; so far, only minor incidents have occurred as a result of people falling from open seated areas, said Ken Scott, head of inspectorate at the Sports Grounds Safety Authority, or SGSA, the U.K. government’s official adviser on safety at sports grounds.  Get weekly insights into the ways companies optimize data, technology and design to drive success with their customers and employees.   Approaches to stadium standing vary outside the U.K. German stadiums such as Borussia Dortmund’s Signal Iduna Park have operated standing zones for decades. In the U.S., a handful of Major League Soccer teams have recently built areas designed to encourage standing, seeking the energetic atmosphere generated by fans on their feet. The teams have installed railings for safety and some have either removed seats or locked them upright in these sections. In addition to heading off potential accidents, the U.K.’s test also represents British soccer’s broader strategy to prioritize the fan experience more than it did in the past, Mr. Scott said. “Going to football matches in the U.K. 20, 30 years ago wasn’t necessarily a pleasurable experience at many of these places because customer service didn’t really feature highly on the agenda,” Mr. Scott said. “Now we’re following very much the example of the American spectator experience, looking at things like the Super Bowl and seeing how it’s very much fan-driven.” Unlike the standing sections of a previous era, the standing spaces being tested include fold-down seats, like those in movie theaters, to accommodate fans who want or need to sit during parts of a game. Computer modeling using virtual crash test dummies of differing sizes led the SGSA to recommend a rail height between 800 and 900 millimeters, equivalent to between 31.5 and 35.4 inches. “It stops you from going over the top if you did suffer a force from behind, but equally it means that if you wish to sit and watch the match, the rail is still at a height that doesn’t obstruct your vision,” Mr. Scott said. The SGSA said its priority will be to monitor the safety of fans during the trial period and work with the clubs involved to identify and resolve any issues. In addition to safety, Manchester United said it would assess fan feedback and the contribution to the stadium atmosphere, while Cardiff City said it would measure elements including compliance with the rules and the customer experience of those standing. The test will finish at the end of the British soccer season in late May, when the SGSA will submit a report on its results to the government. “I fully expect that following that report, they’ll get to roll this out to a wider base of clubs,” Mr. Scott said. “Safe standing is one of the first times I can remember that we’ve ever got something significant across the line that hasn’t required a tragedy to get us to that point.” Write to Katie Deighton at katie.deighton@wsj.com Copyright ©2021 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Title: Match Introduces a Human Matchmaking Element to Its Dating App - WSJ
Text:
https://www.wsj.com/articles/match-introduces-a-human-matchmaking-element-to-its-dating-app-11637269774 










            Match Group Inc.


      has introduced matchmakers to its namesake dating app, offering a small human filter to the romantic suggestions its algorithm generates, the company said. A 50-member team—who have been trained as dating coaches by the company—will select two profiles for participating members each week, drawing from the same algorithmically-generated pool the service already provides.  They will be guided by members’ answers to four questions on, for instance, what a person would change about their dating life, what sort of person a user gravitates toward, and others. The service costs $4.99 a week. The company created the feature because, for some singles, the pandemic has added a degree of urgency to finding a long-term relationship, said









      
      Amarnath Thombre,



      chief executive of Match Group Americas. “People have had enough time to reflect on what really matters to me, what makes me happy,” Mr. Thombre said. “They’re also being a little more clear on who they want to be.”  Get weekly insights into the ways companies optimize data, technology and design to drive success with their customers and employees.   The experts can narrow down the candidate pool, bringing forward people who might be more compatible, said Rachel DeAlto, chief dating expert at Match.  “It is really just going in and highlighting people and helping them to not feel as overwhelmed or frustrated,” she said. Match lets users set up profiles, look at other profiles and chat with the system’s “top picks” for them at no cost, but it charges subscription fees before members can communicate with the full pool of users. Further optional add-ons include sending unlimited “likes” to other users and the ability to boost one’s profile in other members’ search results. Dating services are also competing to enhance the experiences they provide. Match added free video calls in April 2020 as social-distancing made in-person dating harder. Tinder and Hinge, both of which are also owned by Match Group, have added new features as well, such as the new Explore section on Tinder that matches people by their interests. Many dating apps have seen an increase in users during the pandemic. Match Group reported 16.3 million paying subscribers in the third quarter, up from 14 million a year earlier. Company revenue totaled $802 million in the last quarter, an increase from $640 million the year prior. 

 Algorithms can solve many issues, but can’t always decipher context clues between people’s preferences in a dating app, said









      
      Brendan Gahan,



      partner and chief social officer at Mekanism Inc., an ad agency. “We’re not going to solely rely on algorithms—we want a human touch to help bring that human element and encourage that intimacy even further,” he said. Traditional matchmaking services are costly, starting in the thousands of dollars for just a few months. But these services are worth it to customers who don’t have the time to sort through candidates on apps, said









      
      Tammy Shaklee,



      founder and matchmaker of He’s For Me LLC, which operates H4M Matching, an LGBTQ matchmaking service. Matchmakers will contact people only if they think they have identified a potential lifelong partner—not just another date, Ms. Shaklee said. The new Match feature helps humanize online dating, and mirrors things many single people already do, like asking others for advice on whom to date, said









      
      Nick Notas,



      a dating coach for men at Eros Consulting Inc. “The frustration, the loneliness, everything that goes into the online dating experience—it sometimes clouds your judgment, and it is hard to take a step back and look objectively at things,” Mr. Notas said. Title: Inflation’s Warm-Up Act  - WSJ
Text:
Inflation will probably cool next year, but it may still be plenty warm. Right now, inflation is running hot. The Labor Department on Friday reported that consumer prices rose 0.8% in November from October, putting them 6.8% above their year-earlier level, marking the largest year-on-year increase since 1982. A chunk of that was from fuel costs, which have recently started slipping, but core prices, which exclude food and energy prices to better capture inflation’s underlying trend, were still up 4.9% on the year. Title: Opinion: These 6 overvalued stocks are making the S&P 500 look more pricey than it really is - MarketWatch
Date: Last Updated: Dec. 10, 2021 at 5:38 p.m. ET
Text:
It’s impossible to know which stocks will dominate the stock market in a decade’s time, but we can fairly confidently say which companies will not be on that list: stocks that currently top today’s market-cap ranking — namely Apple 
        AAPL,
        +2.80%,
       Microsoft 
        MSFT,
        +2.83%,
       Amazon.com 
        AMZN,
        -1.12%,
       Alphabet (Google) 
        GOOG,
        +0.38%
       and Meta Platforms (Facebook) 
        FB,
        -0.02%.
       That’s because it’s rare for stocks at the top of the market-cap ranking to keep their status a decade later. Not only do they usually fall out of the top 10, they also underperform the market on average over the decade. That’s according to an analysis conducted by Research Affiliates, the investment firm headed by Robert Arnott. To show the precarious position of the market’s “top dogs,” he calculated what happened over the decade of the 1980s to the 10 largest publicly traded companies at the beginning of that 10-year period. Eight of the 10 were not on 1990’s top-10 list, and all 10 on 1980’s list underperformed the world stock market over the subsequent decade. Arnott found that the 1980s were not unique. He reached a similar result for the top stocks of the 1990s, 2000s, and 2010s. On average, a stock on any of these lists underperformed the market over the subsequent decade. In addition, there was between a 70% and 80% chance that any given stock would not be on the comparable list one decade hence. Arnott illustrated these top companies’ underperformance in another way as well: He constructed a hypothetical portfolio that each year owned the world’s 10-largest companies. The performance of this portfolio is plotted in the chart below. Over the 40 years from the end of 1980 through the end of 2020, this portfolio lagged a buy-and-hold by 1.8 annualized percentage points. Numerous investment lessons can be drawn from Arnott’s fascinating results. One is that cap-weighting is not the optimal weighting scheme for your portfolio. Equal-weighting is one obvious alternative, and it has beaten cap-weighting: since 1971, according to data from S&P Dow Jones Indices, the equal-weighted version of the S&P 500 
        SPX,
        +0.95%
       has outperformed the cap-weighted version by 1.5 annualized percentage points. Arnott believes there are even better ways of weighting stocks in an index beyond equal weighting. His firm maintains a number of so-called fundamental indices that base a stock’s weight on fundamental characteristics such as sales, cash flow, dividends and book equity value. 
        “Just six stocks — Apple, Microsoft, Alphabet, Amazon, Tesla and Meta Platforms — account for 26% of the S&P 500’s total market cap”
       But there’s another investment implication of Arnott’s data that I want to focus on: His results highlight the difficulties determining the valuation of a lopsided market.  Consider the S&P 500 currently, in which just six stocks — Apple, Microsoft, Alphabet, Amazon, Tesla 
        TSLA,
        +1.32%
       and Meta Platforms — account for 26% of the index’s total market cap. Imagine a situation in which those six are overvalued while the other 494 stocks, on balance, are more fairly valued. In that case, the valuation ratios for the S&P 500 as a whole could paint a skewed picture. This situation isn’t just hypothetical. The largest six stocks currently have an average price/earnings ratio of 62.0, according to FactSet, more than double the average across all stocks in the S&P 500 of 29.1 and almost triple its median P/E ratio of 21.4. It’s possible, therefore, that the stock market isn’t as overvalued as we would otherwise think by focusing on valuation ratios for the S&P 500 as a whole. Title: Megamansion on Canada’s Niagara River Lists for C$4.79 million - Mansion Global
Text: A more than 8,550-square-foot mansion on the Niagara River in Ontario, Canada, has hit the market for C$4.79 million (US$3.76 million).  Located in the city of Niagara Falls, Ontario, the five-bedroom, seven-bathroom home is about 6 miles down river from the famous Horseshoe Falls. The home features 200 feet of water frontage with dock rights, according to the listing with Nancy Bailey of Engel & Völkers Oakville brokerage.  “Enjoy roller blading, power walking and cycling right outside your door on the Niagara Trail,” she said in the listing, which went live in November. “With its privileged location and dramatic design, this is the epitome of grand living.” More: Nearly 700-Year-Old U.K. Residence With Modern Updates Lists for £4.25 Million The home sits on just over an acre behind wrought iron gates, with stone patios surrounding the home for dining and other activities, listing photos show. The landscaped grounds feature hedgerows and other plantings.  Inside, the great room has vaulted ceilings and French doors that lead outside. There’s also a formal dining room with a fireplace and a built-in china closet, plus an eat-in kitchen with exposed ceiling beams, an island, a pizza oven and wine storage, plus a round breakfast nook in one of the turrets overlooking the river.  There’s also a billiards room with a wet bar, a two-story, wood-clad library with a wrought-iron spiral staircase, a primary bedroom suite with a sitting area, a gym and a bathroom with two vanities, a soaking tub and a stand-up shower, listing photos show.  From Penta: Great Escapes: The Underrated, Elegant Luxuries Of Osaka There’s also a four-car garage, additional parking for 16 cars on the grounds and two laundry rooms, according to the listing.  Mansion Global could not determine when the property traded last or for how much. Title: Kirk Douglas’s Long-Time Beverly Hills Home, Complete With Hollywood Walk of Fame, Listed for $7.49M - Mansion Global
Text: The  Beverly Hills home of Hollywood legends Kirk and Anne Douglas and its garden pathway of pavers signed by Tinseltown’s biggest stars has hit the market for $7.495 million. The 1920s property, which is in The Flats neighborhood that’s hidden from the street by tall hedges, is close to Rodeo Drive and the Beverly Hills Hotel. It was listed on Dec. 6 by Rochelle Altas Maize of Nourmand & Associates.  Placed in a trust in 1990, the Douglases bought the property in 1976 for $400,000, according to its listing on Redfin. Ms. Maize said the couple lived in the house until their deaths: He died in 2020 at 103, and she passed away this year at 102. More: Rupert Murdoch Buys $200 Million Montana Ranch From the Koch Family Set on a little more than a third of an acre that features mature trees and gardens, the estate includes a single-story 4,648-square-foot main house and a two-story guest house. The main house, which has four bedrooms and six bathrooms, is relatively modest for a celebrity couple of such stature, Ms. Maize said. It is the backyard Walk of Fame that sets the property apart, Ms. Maize said. “They entertained a lot, and I was told that Kirk would have people autograph cement pavers at dinner parties,” she said. “There are 22 stones—some were from their previous property.” When she toured the property, she spent over an hour stepping through the stars, photographing and writing down the autographed names. More: Jim Belushi Sells Los Angeles Home for $30 Million After Four Years on the Market “It’s like Grauman’s Chinese Theatre’s Hollywood Walk of Fame on steroids,” she said, adding that it’s “iconic and special.” In addition to a stone signed by Kirk Douglas and his four show-biz sons – Michael, Joel, Peter and Eric—she documented a roster of other celebrities, including Milton Berle, Dean Martin, Frank Sinatra, Ronald Reagan, Lucille Ball, Elizabeth Taylor, Barbra Streisand and countless others members of Hollywood royalty. “I didn’t count all the signatures,” she said. “Some of the stones have three or four names.” The home’s other amenities include paneled rooms, fireplaces, French doors that open to a brick patio, a massive skylight, a breakfast bar, a butler’s pantry and a formal dining room that has a stained-glass ceiling. Kirk Douglas, who was one of the last surviving stars of Hollywood’s so-called Golden Age, was at the height of his career when in 1951 he divorced his first wife, Diana Dill, the mother of three of his four sons, and married Anne Buydens in 1954. Over the years, he starred in more than 90 films, receiving an Academy Honorary Award for Lifetime Achievement. For his philanthropic work, he was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom. A film producer, Anne received a Jefferson Award for Public Service in 2003.   Because of the limited inventory in Beverly Hills, the celebrity cachet and the unusual autographed pavers, Ms. Maize said she expects the property to sell quickly. “I priced it at land value,” she said. “And nothing in Beverly Hills that’s great sells for less than $9 million. We are accepting offers starting on Monday, and I expect to get 15 or more and for it to sell for substantially over the asking price.” The Douglas children did not reply to an email requesting comment. Title: Nearly 700-Year-Old U.K. Residence With Modern Updates Lists for £4.25 Million - Mansion Global
Text: A nearly 700-year-old U.K. home, part of which was once used by the Archbishops of Canterbury, has hit the market for a guide price of £4.25 million (US$5.6 million). Known as the Old Palace, the 5,985-square-foot residence sits on close to 6.5 acres in the village of Wrotham, near Sevenoaks in Kent. It features all of the charm of a period home, but has been updated with modern amenities, according to the listing with Savills, which brought the property to the market last month.  “It has the delight of an old period build with an unbelievable amount of history,” said Savills agent Oliver Hodges. “But it’s been stitched together really well with an indoor pool and spa.” More: Offers for London Homes Hit 10-Year High in November The oldest part of the structure, which dates to 1340, was once a kitchen wing of the “long since demolished Archbishop’s Palace,” the listing said. The property has a Grade II* listing because of its impressive past, a designation given to structures of more than special interest, according to the preservation group Historic England. The Archbishops of Canterbury once used the palace as a stopover as they traveled to and from London, according to listing records cited by Savills. Most of the original structure was destroyed, and the materials were used to build the Maidstone Palace, also in Kent.  That accessibility to London remains a desirable attribute of the property, Mr. Hodges explained. Guests and residents can travel easily between London and the home, which is about 30 miles each way.  At the same time, “there’s a pub close by, so you definitely get that in-the-middle-of-a-village vibe,” the agent added.  From Penta: Electric Air Taxis Are About to Take Off The residence has seven bedrooms, six bathrooms and four reception rooms, the listing said. Design elements include high ceilings, exposed wooden beams, stone mullion windows, old and modern oak internal doors, a custom kitchen by New York City-based Smallbone and bathroom suites by Villeroy & Boch, a German manufacturer. A gated driveway leads to the home, which is surrounded by manicured lawns and gardens. There’s also a two-bedroom cottage and a six-bay garage with storage space above.  The property last traded in December 2014 for £3.25 million, according to records with the U.K. Land Registry. Title: Lamborghini’s CEO Has His Sights Set on Electrification | Barron's
Text:
This copy is for your personal, non-commercial use only. To order presentation-ready copies for distribution to your colleagues, clients or customers visit http://www.djreprints.com. https://www.barrons.com/articles/lamborghinis-ceo-has-his-sights-set-on-electrification-01639171925 
Elon Musk
 is frequently lauded for simultaneously leading two companies, Tesla and Space X. Another executive who pulled off the same feat got less attention. He’s 
Stephan Winkelmann,
 who, for a year, helmed both Bugatti and Lamborghini—and still has the second role.  Winkelmann was already president of Bugatti in December 2020 when he signed on—again—as the top executive at Lamborghini. He also held that role from 2005 to 2016.  On Dec. 2, Winkelmann was in Greenwich, Conn., for the launch of Lamborghini Greenwich, a new multi-story facility operated by RDS Automotive Group, which also has dealerships for the brand in Philadelphia and Newport Beach, Calif., and also sells Maserati, Porsche, and 
McLaren
 cars.  “This is our 38th dealership in the U.S.,” Winkelmann tells Penta in the dealership’s conference room. “It’s a new location and new construction. Greenwich is a huge market for us, because it’s a prime place where wealthy individuals live.”  With an average household income of US$209,877, there’s a reason the Lamborghini Urus SUV, which has a starting price of US$218,009, is popular in Greenwich. In an indication of where car buying is going in wealthy communities like Greenwich, the town has the largest number of electric vehicle (
EV
) registrations in the state, followed by Stamford and then Westport (home base for the EV Club of Connecticut).  Lamborghini is moving quickly toward electrification. “We follow the dreams of our customers,” Winkelmann says. Currently Lamborghini offers as its main models the Huracan, Aventador, and Urus, as well as some limited-edition vehicles such as a Countach for the 21st century, called the LPI 800-4. The limited-to-63 
Sián,
 unveiled in 2019, is a mild hybrid that uses a supercapacitor for added oomph during rapid acceleration. There are also 19 Sián roadsters.  “The whole range will be plug-in hybrid by late 2024,” Winkelmann says. “Our fourth model will be our first electric car.” No dates or specifications are available for the battery EV yet, and Winkelmann didn’t offer an all-electric range for the hybrids. “We don’t have to decide today,” he says. The EV will reportedly be a four-seat model, and it could use a wide variety of technology developed for Group members Porsche, Audi, or VW itself. This is an enormous change for Lamborghini, which like Ferrari is famous for its V12 internal-combustion engines—going back to the company’s founding in 1963 by Ferruccio Lamborghini. The founder sold the company in 1974, and since then it’s been owned by various business conglomerates, and then Chrysler, followed in 1998 by Volkswagen (where it’s under Audi’s jurisdiction). The purchase price back then was around US$110 million. It’s since gained quite a bit of value.  Winkelmann is unsure how long internal-combustion cars will still be on the road, but Lamborghini is definitely phasing them out. The overall timetable for the auto fleet’s transition to batteries remains unclear. “There are hundreds of millions of internal-combustion cars now that will still be on the road in 2030,” he says. “What happens to them depends on legislation, and perhaps the development of cleaner synthetic fuels.” Lamborghini is aiming to reduce its carbon emissions 50 percent by 2025.  Lamborghini has enhanced its brand by opening lounges, so far in New York and Tokyo. Winkelmann said other locations soon could be London, Los Angeles, or Miami—which is fast becoming an auto center. But he said Lamborghini also has another venture—in Dubai. “We are building 40 six-bedroom villas, to be completed by 2026. They are homes, not skyscrapers or towers.”  The Dubai Hills Vista development with Emaar Properties, announced in November, is already sold out. It’s part of Emaar’s Dubai Hill’s Estate, 20 minutes from Dubai International Airport and the city’s downtown. A photo shows a two-story modern home with lots of glass, a pool, and a Lamborghini in the driveway. But there are four different types, each with Lamborghini-inspired furniture and interior design.  
Federico Foschini,
 chief marketing and sales officer of Automobili Lamborghini, said in a statement, “Forty discerning real-estate investors have chosen a Dubai Hills Vista villa, privileged with sophisticated interiors inspired by the Automobili Lamborghini brand that bring its essence to everyday life.” Despite the market challenges, Winkelmann thinks that 2021 will be a record sales year for the company, surpassing 2019. “We have had to increase production twice,” he says. “We are living in a crazy time.” The U.S. remains Lamborghini’s biggest market, and the Urus SUV is more than 50 percent of sales.  Elon Musk is frequently lauded for simultaneously leading two companies, Tesla and Space X. Title: Great Escapes: The Underrated, Elegant Luxuries Of Osaka | Barron's
Text:
This copy is for your personal, non-commercial use only. To order presentation-ready copies for distribution to your colleagues, clients or customers visit http://www.djreprints.com. https://www.barrons.com/articles/great-escapes-the-underrated-elegant-luxuries-of-osaka-01639167760 There is a certain romanticism associated with Japan’s third-largest city, Osaka, a name that conjures up enticing wonders of faraway Japan. “In reality, Osaka is a bustling metropolis of sparkling skyscrapers, blinking storefronts, and three million souls—a concrete jungle. And yet there is real elegance there. In Osaka, one finds the luxuries of a fully modern Japan intimately shaped by its regal past.  Among Japanese today, Osakans have a reputation for being direct, down to earth, and generally inviting. In Osaka, it is not uncommon for a traveler asking for directions from a passerby to be invited out for a drink or a meal of okonomiyaki, a grilled cabbage pancake and Osaka street-food speciality. Despite their fast-paced life and imposing sprawl, Osakans are warm.  Their friendliness perhaps stems from a long history interacting with outsiders as one of Japan’s largest trading centers. A sea port cut up by rivers and canals, this “city of water” has been an important axis of Pacific Ocean commerce from at least the 16th century. Specializing in foodstuffs, Osaka has long been known as the “kitchen of the nation.” Economic historians pinpoint the world’s first futures-trading to the city’s Dojima Rice Exchange, opened in 1697. Today, Osaka’s port remains one of Japan’s five largest and its culinary scene remains storied.  STAY For classic luxury and prime location, there’s the Ritz-Carlton Osaka in the bright and hurried Umeda district. Styled after an 18th-century English manor, with fine wood, sparkling chandeliers, and an ornate fireplace lobby straight out of Knightsbridge, this large hotel sits in the center of Osaka’s beating heart just a stone’s throw from Osaka Station, the city’s main train terminus; this is the go-to nexus for exploring Osaka’s many worthwhile satellite cities such as Kobe, Nara, and Kyoto.  For the Japanese touch, dine on excellent sashimi and top-shelf sake at the Michelin-starred Hanagatami Restaurant. Don’t skip a green tea on the 34th-floor Club Lounge, which offers unparalleled cityscape views.  For lodgings in a quieter quarter, check out the St. Regis on Midosuji Boulevard, Osaka’s main north-south thoroughfare, lined with ginkgo trees. Boasting a bevy of luxury outlets–Armani, Louis Vuitton, Chanel–the storied street is known as the Champs-Elysee of Osaka. This 160-room 
St. Regis
 features a world-class spa and uber-attentive “Butler Service.” Outside its high-ceilinged, 12th-floor lobby rests a charming garden terrace and rock garden, or karesansui, overlooking the trendy Minami district.  To escape the urban bustle all together, hop on a 30-minute shinkansen fast train to Kyoto and spend a night lounging in your own personal onsen at the Suiran Hotel (buy a rail pass here.) Located along the tranquil, jade-green Hozu River beside the 
Kameyama
 forest, this smallish retreat in the refined 
Arashiyama
 neighborhood tastefully fuses traditional Kyoto aesthetics with modern elegance and amenities. Guests enjoy a complimentary drink every evening in their riverside restaurant, Kyo-Suiran, a former summer residence built during the 19th-century Meiji Restoration.  EXPERIENCE  In Osaka, one of the first places visitors go is Dotonbori, and for good reason. A long, frenzied stretch of casual dining, shopping, and entertainment running alongside a picturesque canal, Dotonbori is best visited at night to fully appreciate the light show of neon winking storefronts. Many feature giant animatronic mascots, such as the iconic orange spider crab enticing passersby above the 
Koni Daraku
 restaurant. Pro tip: duck into one of Dotonbori’s many narrow side streets to find a less touristy eatery to try.  The next morning, take a leisurely stroll around the stupendous 
Osaka Castle,
 one of Japan’s most iconic archeological treasures. Constructed in the 16th century, it sits behind tall ancient walls on a lovely island surrounded by a wide moat. Numerous gardens, a small museum and fashionable gift shops provide plenty for the leisurely visitor to explore.  Osaka is a popular jumping off point for nearby day trips. The nearest worthwhile destination is the temple town of Kyoto, one of Japan’s most charming municipalities, boasting 17 UNESCO World Heritage Sites, and only half an hour away by shinkansen. Its 1,600 Buddhist temples are a main draw, as are its many elegant teahouses. Recommended is the brightly gilded Kinkaju-ji, the subject of 
Yukio Mishima’s
 poignant novel, The Temple of the Golden Pavilion, based on a real-life arson incident at the site in 1950.    EAT & DRINK Osaka is one of the world’s greatest food cities, though few outside of Japan know it. Fine dining in particular abounds and the metropolis is littered with Michelin stars. One eatery with three of those famed stars is Fujiya 1935. The small, sparse restaurant boasts a seasonal, ever-changing menu of inventive, Euro-Japanese dishes that are colorful as they are scrumptious. Think ginkgo nut crepe with pacific saury and finger lime, or chestnut pudding with rum-flavored coffee jelly.  Another three-star must-try is Koryu, the seafood-heavy brainchild of chef 
Shintaro Matsuo,
 who was born and educated in the culinary arts in Osaka. With room for only a handful of diners, there is no menu; Matsuo-san uses whichever ingredients are freshest that day. Expect lots of raw fish and a friendly hello, from the genial chef.  After dinner, make your way to Bar K, a tiny, dimly-lit basement speakeasy in the clubby Kita Shinchi District. With an impressive collection of Scottish single malt whiskey, it is one of Osaka’s finest drinking holes–they also make what might be the best mojito you’ll ever try. For gin-lovers, there is Bar Juniper, a sleek, classic kind of place with handsomely-dressed bartenders and a rich 
bevvy
 of gin varieties, some up to a century old.  The writer was hosted by St. Regis, the Ritz Carlton, and the Suiran.  There is a certain romanticism associated with Japan’s third-largest city, Osaka, a name that conjures up enticing wonders of faraway Japan. Title: Electric Air Taxis Are About to Take Off | Barron's
Text:
This copy is for your personal, non-commercial use only. To order presentation-ready copies for distribution to your colleagues, clients or customers visit http://www.djreprints.com. https://www.barrons.com/articles/electric-air-taxis-are-about-to-take-off-01639072187 As industry experts ponder the future of travel, thoughts increasingly turn to the sky. A range of big names—from aviation stalwarts to well-funded start-ups—are working to make electric air taxis a reality. While the sector is in its infancy and several key factors remain uncertain, many insiders believe we’ll see what in industry parlance are called electric vertical-takeoff-and-landing (eVTOL) aircraft take to the skies in the near future. “New technologies have often been met with skepticism,” says Balkiz Sarihan, Airbus’ head of UAM (urban air mobility) strategy execution and partnerships. “Remember the smartphone, which was depicted as a luxury item and now has become an integrated part of our lives. Today, nobody can imagine life without one.”  Airbus has emerged as a major player in the sector, having started eVTOL activities in 2014 that led to the development of two demonstrators: Vahana, a single-seat, tilt-wing, self-piloted model; and CityAirbus, a four-seat, remotely piloted multicopter that features four ducted, high-lift propulsion units. Flight testing with those two vehicles has now finished; in total they performed 242 flight and ground tests and flew over 600 miles.  Skeptics point to a lack of a proven business model, while questioning whether the public will embrace the sort of futuristic vessels that look like they belong to a science-fiction villain. Prototypes and renderings of eVTOLs resemble a helicopter crossed with a small airplane, with curved, aerodynamic features.  Headwinds & Tailwinds  A key question without a common answer is who will fly these planes. A handful of companies are focusing on single-passenger aircraft, meaning the customer will be responsible for certain functions, and others feature multiple seats with room for a pilot, though industry experts don’t think it will be financially feasible for companies to find, train, and pay the number of pilots required for widespread operations. Naysayers also wonder about the inevitable regulatory hurdles—the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration has never approved electric aircraft, pilotless or otherwise—plus noise issues and other practical matters such as whether eVTOLs will need landing pads. Advocates, however, say air taxis would provide relief from the traffic- choked streets that slow down business and make the world’s megacities frustrating to navigate.  California-based Archer Aviation has signed a $1 billion aircraft purchase and collaboration agreement with United Airlines Holdings, making Archer the first eVTOL company to gain a contract from a major airline.  Archer claims it will be able to transport passengers from San Francisco to San Jose in California in 20 minutes rather than 90, or from Manhattan to John F. Kennedy International Airport in just 10 minutes.  But most eVTOLs are expected to be priced in the hundreds of thousands and up, making them out of reach to most individual buyers. Most companies will likely adopt a ride-hailing and -sharing model similar to Uber’s, which would enable the aircraft costs to be shared among many riders.  Archer’s battery-powered aircraft are designed to travel at speeds of up to 150 miles per hour for up to 60 miles at a time. The company has announced the development of UAM networks in its launch cities of Los Angeles and Miami. At launch, Archer is estimating the price to be $3.30 per passenger mile, then decreasing over time as more aircraft become available.  Says 
Brett Adcock,
 Archer’s co-founder, “This new mode of transportation will revolutionize the way we interact with and move around urban environments.”  This article appears in the December 2021 issue of Penta magazine. Title: Athletes and Mental Health: A Long-Overdue Conversation - WSJ
Text:
https://www.wsj.com/articles/athletes-mental-health-11638301882 Conversations about the intersection between mental health and sport have come out of the proverbial shadows. The evolution is long overdue. Over the past few years, athletes from various sports have courageously shared their personal experiences in regard to mental health, and a consistent theme has been the demand that we see them as people first, no longer reducing their identity to one that lives exclusively in their performances or sport. Yes, they have extraordinary gifts and abilities, but that doesn’t diminish their humanity and desire to be seen in the fullness of who they are as people.
